column1: In a rice cooker bowl: Wash the rice 3-4 times until water is clear. Drain all the water from the rice.

Add coconut milk and water mixture to the rice
Add the ingredients from the spices section and mix well","Cups Long Grain Basmati Rice

column4: A few Coriander and Mint leaves
column5: In a rice cooker bowl: Wash the rice 3-4 times until water is clear. Drain all the water from the rice.
column6: Make a mixture of coconut milk and 6 cups of water

column1: Hoppers,"500 g white rice
Wash the rice and soak the rice for 4 hours. Drain the rice.
In a blender put rice coconut milk, sugar, salt, yeast and egg. Blend The rice and remaining until become a paste. Consistency should be thinner than pancake batter.
In a bowel add the mixer. Keep for rest for about 2 hours. The mixer should double in size.
Heat Hopper pan and some oil. Add 1/4 cup Hopper batter in centre of pan and swirl around cover and cook for 3 - 5 minutes
Loosen Hopper with knife and serve.","ml thick coconut milk
column2: Wash the rice and soak the rice for 4 hours. Drain the rice.
column3: In a blender put rice coconut milk, sugar, salt, yeast and egg. Blend The rice and remaining until become a paste. Consistency should be thinner than pancake batter.
column4: In a bowel add the mixer. Keep for rest for about 2 hours. The mixer should double in size.
column5: Heat Hopper pan and some oil. Add 1/4 cup Hopper batter in centre of pan and swirl around cover and cook for 3 - 5 minutes
column6: Loosen Hopper with knife and serve.

column1: #mycookbook
Beetroot String Hoppers,"1 cup rice flour (roasted)
Wash, peel and chop beetroot. Add one and 1/4 cup water and blend it well. If needs pass through sieve and strain it.
Add beetroot juice, ghee and salt in one pan and let it boil.
Once it starts boiling, slow down the flame and add rice flour little by little, while stirring continuously.
Stir continuously till dough like mass is formed. Turn off the heat, cover and rest it for 5 minutes.","cup rice flour (roasted)
column4: Wash, peel and chop beetroot. Add one and 1/4 cup water and blend it well. If needs pass through sieve and strain it.
column5: Add beetroot juice, ghee and salt in one pan and let it boil.
column6: Once it starts boiling, slow down the flame and add rice flour little by little, while stirring continuously.
column7: Stir continuously till dough like mass is formed. Turn off the heat, cover and rest it for 5 minutes.
column8: After 5 minutes, with wet hands, knead the dough till it becomes smooth. Be careful, dough will be very hot. Then grease the extruder, set sev plate and fill it with prepared dough. In a greased plate prepare string hoppers by moving extruder.
column9: Now place this plate in steamer and steam cook it for 10-15 minutes.
column10: For tempering, heat oil and prepare by all tempering ingredients and pour it over string hoppers.

column1: Stuffed Sweet Idiyappam (Sweet String Hoppers),"1 1/2 cup Rice Flour
column5: 1/2 cup Crushed Jaggery (Or more, as per desired sweetness)
column6: 1 tsp Cardamom Flavoring Substance or 1/2 tsp Cardamom Powder

column1: First step is to prepare the coconut-jaggery filling. In a mixing bowl, add the freshly grated coconut, crushed/grated jaggery, salt and cardamom flavoring substance or cardamom powder. Mix it well and set it aside.
Keep the measured rice flour ready.

In a kadai add water, salt and ghee. When the water starts boiling, add in the rice flour. Stir quickly till all the water is absorbed. Switch off the flame. Cover and let it rest for few minutes. Transfer it to a bowl. When it cools down a bit, wet your palm with water and knead it. Add little water, if required. Add little ghee and knead till the dough becomes soft. Meanwhile, add water in rice cooker/steamer and let it reach boiling point.

Take idiyappam maker. Brush the inside of the idiyappam maker with oil/ghee. Place the dough inside and start making idiyappam on a silicon mould/butter paper/banana leaves. Place a generous amount of the coconut-jaggery filling over the idiyappam. Again start making idiyappam over the filling.
Place the mould in the rice cooker/steamer. Close the lid and allow it to cook for 18-20 minutes. Remove the mould from the rice cooker/steamer and let it rest for few minutes, before serving.

Alternatively, you can wet your palm and pinch a portion of the rice dough and form it into a ball. Press and form it into a pocket shape. Add a tablespoon of the coconut-jaggery filling. Bring the ends together and form in desired shape. Place it in a silicon mould.
Place the mould in the rice cooker/steamer and steam for 18-20 minutes. Remove the mould from the rice cooker/steamer and let it rest for few minutes, before serving.
Transfer it into a serving plate. Serve it as a snack or for breakfast.

column6: tsp Cardamom Flavoring Substance or 1/2 tsp Cardamom Powder

column1: Murungai Keerai Poricha Kottu,"2 cups Murungai keerai or Moringa
Pressure cook moong dal with turmeric powder for 2 whistles.
In a pan add washed keerai and one cup water to it.Add salt as per your taste and allow it to cook for 5 to 8 minutes.
Grind grated coconut,green chillies,cumin seeds,pepper to a fine paste and keep it aside.
Add the cooked moong dal to the keerai in the pan and bring to a boil.Add the grinded coconut paste and let it cook for 4 mins on low flame till the raw smell goes off.
Heat a pan with oil or ghee and season with mustard seeds,red chilli and hing.Pour the seasoning over the keerai kottu.","cups Murungai keerai or Moringa

column1: Homestyle Beef Massaman Curry,"1
Heat the coconut cream in a pan until it comes to a boil; you don't need to wait for the oil to separate.
Add the beef and stir until it's partially cooked.
Pour the mixture into a pot where you've already heated the coconut milk.
Stir until the coconut oil separates, then add salt, palm sugar, and tamarind juice to taste.
Let it simmer for 15 minutes, stirring and checking the consistency. If you want it thicker, add more coconut cream and adjust the seasonings as needed.
Once everything is well combined and cooked through, it's ready to serve.","Beef, your preferred cut
column2: Heat the coconut cream in a pan until it comes to a boil; you don't need to wait for the oil to separate.
column3: Add the beef and stir until it's partially cooked.
column4: Pour the mixture into a pot where you've already heated the coconut milk.
column5: Stir until the coconut oil separates, then add salt, palm sugar, and tamarind juice to taste.
column6: Let it simmer for 15 minutes, stirring and checking the consistency. If you want it thicker, add more coconut cream and adjust the seasonings as needed.
column7: Once everything is well combined and cooked through, it's ready to serve.

column1: Massaman Chicken Curry,1/2 teaspoon salt
column12: 1/8 teaspoon ground cinnamon
column14: 2 cardamom pods
column15: 1/2 teaspoon star anise,"teaspoon shrimp paste
column17: 5 ounce cilantro roots (15 grams)
column26: First, cut the chicken into two parts: separate the drumstick from the thigh. If you bought them already separated, you can skip this step. To cut the chicken, slice through the joint instead of the bone for easier preparation.
column27: Wash the potatoes thoroughly, peel them, and cut into large chunks. Since you'll be simmering the curry until the chicken is tender, large potato pieces will hold their shape better and not fall apart.
column28: Next, toast all the spices except the ground cinnamon in a pan until fragrant. Be careful not to burn them‚Äîturn off the heat as soon as they're aromatic.
column29: Once the spices are toasted, heat some vegetable oil in a pan. When hot, fry the lemongrass, galangal, garlic, and dried chilies until they are fragrant and crispy.
column30: Gradually pound the toasted spices and curry paste ingredients in a mortar and pestle until fine. Then add the shallots, garlic, galangal, and fried dried chilies, and continue pounding until smooth. This step takes some time, but keep going‚Äîit's worth it!
column31: When the curry paste is smooth, heat a pot and add the coconut milk, chicken, potatoes, and curry paste. Simmer until the chicken is cooked through. To check if the chicken is done, see if the skin near the joint pulls away easily. Once cooked, season to taste while the pot is still on the heat.
column32: That's it‚Äîyour Massaman Chicken Curry is ready! There are many more tips for choosing the best spices, so feel free to ask if you're interested.

column1: Massaman Chicken Curry,"5 large chicken drumsticks
Heat a pot over medium heat. Add the coconut cream and simmer until it starts to boil. Add the curry paste and cook until the oil separates from the coconut cream.
Add sliced onions and stir-fry.
- Add the chicken drumsticks and stir to coat with the curry sauce.
- Add the cashews (use plain roasted cashews; salted ones will make the curry too salty).
- Add the potatoes and stir.
- Add the sliced onions and stir.
- Add the chicken drumsticks.
Add the coconut milk.
- Simmer until the chicken is tender, about 45‚Äì60 minutes. Stir occasionally to prevent the bottom from burning.
- Add more coconut milk if needed.
- Simmer until the chicken is soft.
Add the coconut sugar.
- Add the tamarind paste.
- Add the fish sauce and salt.
- Continue simmering until everything is well combined. Serve hot.
- Add the coconut sugar.
- Simmer until well blended, then serve.","large chicken drumsticks

- Continue simmering until everything is well combined. Serve hot.

- Simmer until well blended, then serve.

column1: Easy Chicken Massaman Curry (Jum's Style),"4 1/4 cups coconut milk (about 1000 ml, 1 carton)
column7: 2-3 tablespoons vegetable oil (for stir-frying the curry paste)

column1: Heat the oil in a pan. Add the curry paste and stir-fry until fragrant. Add about 1 cup of coconut milk and cook until aromatic and the oil separates.
Gradually add the remaining coconut milk, about half the pot. Once it comes to a boil, add the chicken.
While the chicken is cooking, cut the onions and potatoes, and wash the tomatoes. Set aside.
Simmer the chicken until it starts to cook through, then add the onions and potatoes.
Add the roasted peanuts and season with palm sugar, fish sauce, and tamarind paste to taste. (Taste and adjust as you like; I prefer it slightly sweet.)
Simmer for another 15-20 minutes, then add the tomatoes and turn off the heat. The tomatoes will continue to cook in the hot curry.
Serve hot with steamed rice or enjoy with roti.","1/4 cups coconut milk (about 1000 ml, 1 carton)
column7: Palm sugar to taste - fish sauce to taste - tamarind paste to taste

column1: Beef Massaman Curry,"3 1/2 oz Massaman curry paste (100 grams)
Heat the coconut milk in a pot until hot. Add the beef and simmer until cooked, then set aside.
In a separate pan, cook the coconut cream over medium heat until the oil separates. Add the curry paste and stir-fry until fragrant.

Add the coconut cream and curry paste mixture to the pot with the coconut milk and beef. Add roasted peanuts and onions. Season with palm sugar, tamarind paste, bitter orange juice, and fish sauce. Taste and adjust so the flavor is salty first, followed by sweet and sour. Simmer over low heat until the beef is tender.
Add the potatoes, cardamom pods, and bay leaves. Simmer again until boiling, then remove from heat.","1/2 oz Massaman curry paste (100 grams)
column12: Heat the coconut milk in a pot until hot. Add the beef and simmer until cooked, then set aside.

column15: Add the potatoes, cardamom pods, and bay leaves. Simmer again until boiling, then remove from heat.

In a separate pot, bring the coconut milk to a boil. Add the bamboo shoots and simmer for a few minutes.

column1: Beef Massaman Curry,"14 oz beef shank (about 400 grams)
column4: 1 tablespoon coriander seeds, toasted and ground

column1: Cut the beef into 2- to 3-inch cubes. Peel the potatoes and onions, then cut them into chunks similar in size to the beef. Pound the red curry paste together with the cumin and ground toasted coriander seeds until well mixed and fragrant‚Äîthis will be your Massaman curry paste.

Heat a pan over medium heat and pour in about 1/2 cup (100 ml) of coconut milk. Add the curry paste and cook, stirring, until the coconut milk releases its oil. (No vegetable oil needed for this recipe.) Be careful not to let the coconut milk dry out; if it does, just add a bit more coconut milk.
Add the beef and stir-fry until just browned. Pour in enough coconut milk to cover the beef.
Continue cooking; the beef will start to release its juices and the coconut milk will become rich and colorful.
Add the potatoes and the rest of the coconut milk. Simmer until the potatoes are cooked through. If the liquid reduces too much, add just enough water to cover the beef and potatoes.
Add the onions. Season with fish sauce, palm sugar, and tamarind paste. Taste and adjust so the flavors are balanced‚Äîsalty, sweet, and tangy, with no one flavor overpowering the others.

Finally, add the roasted peanuts. Simmer on low heat for another 10 minutes to tenderize the beef. The curry should be thick, not watery. Serve hot‚Äîit's delicious with toasted bread.","oz beef shank (about 400 grams)
column4: tablespoon coriander seeds, toasted and ground

column14: Add the onions. Season with fish sauce, palm sugar, and tamarind paste. Taste and adjust so the flavors are balanced‚Äîsalty, sweet, and tangy, with no one flavor overpowering the others.
column15: Finally, add the roasted peanuts. Simmer on low heat for another 10 minutes to tenderize the beef. The curry should be thick, not watery. Serve hot‚Äîit's delicious with toasted bread.
